body: definitely a bug, thanks for reporting
let's not forget to reproduce the problem before fixing it (at least the `@Immutable`)

@yegor256 of course, done already

@carlosmiranda many thanks for your contribution, I just added 15 mins to your account (ID: `DA2172757`)
@longtimeago can you please help? Keep in mind [this](http://www.tpc2.com/dev/principles). If you have any technical questions, don't hesitate to ask right here
@longtimeago The budget of this issue is **30 mins**, which is exactly how much will be paid when the task is _done_ (see [this](http://www.tpc2.com/dev/principles) for explanation)

@yegor256 Please, clarify what do you mean by "let's not forget to reproduce the problem before fixing it (at least the @Immutable)" ? Write a test to show that class is actually mutable?
As far as I see, class is final, all fields are final and immutable. So, I don't understand what to reproduce

Let's solve this problem in a nicer way. Let's introduce a new test class called, say, `com.jcabi.ImmutabilityTest`. This test will check that all classes in all our packages have `@Immutable` annotation.

Later we'll be able to add more tests, like `com.jcabi.EqualityTest`, and `com.jcabi.StringabilityTest`, etc. Each of them will check certain characteristics applicable to **all** our classes.

What do you think?
@yegor256 Good idea! Actually, I think there would be enough to have one test file  (e.g. `com.jcabi.AnnotationsTest`) with 3 test methods

yes, but I would prefer a few of them. the reason is that we're testing not annotations, but characteristics of our classes. if tomorrow we change the way to achieve the same characteristics, for example without annotations, our tests will still pass. got the point?

@yegor256 I've got your point. There are two questions:
1) Where should I put common code used to gathering and filtering class information?
2) What should I do with classes, which do not have `@Immutable` annotation now? For example 
- `com.jcabi.github.mock.JsonNode`
- `com.jcabi.github.Smarts`
  ...
